comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Looks Like the Hibernian Bank is in the position of the DBC (1916) building,  replaced by a cinema and then the bank in 1951

As  [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] reported in the notes on the following photograph.  The DIA says the Grand Central Cinema was on the site, and suffered a fire in December 1933, was altered in 1946 and converted to the Hibernian Bank in 1951.
But it doesn't say which year the cinema was built...

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03/8491917382/in/photolist-dWpibE-e4GLX5-dCxSvB-bk3Evu-as8FqT-aRPN1i-dv1mhZ-bC5P8b-cC6jHE]

comment._content: irishphotoarchive.photoshelter.com/image/I0000MaK_1pjzdHE Here is a REAL photo of Sean South from 04/01/1957 - with Green Buses I am Surprised to read that he died on active service in 1956/7 always presumed he was much earlier!! Funeral of Sean South.04/01/1957..Seán South (1928–1 January 1957) was a member of an IRA military column led by Sean Garland on a raid against a Royal Ulster Constabulary barracks in Brookeborough, County Fermanagh, Northern Ireland on New Year's Day, 1957. South died of wounds sustained during the raid along with another IRA volunteer,

comment.author: 63429800@N06
comment._content: The linked funeral photo from DannyM8 has to be much later than 1957 as there are Leyland Atlantean buses in the background (see Podhead's comment on the funeral photo). The hearse cannot be a Roscommon reg as the ADI (Roscommon) prefix would only have run from ADI 1 to ADI 999. It is probably a Northern AOI reg as the Northern reg system ran from 1 to 9999 after three-letter prefixes.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] More Poetry about the Bovril sign in College Green.

Samuel Beckett’s collection of short prose More Pricks Than Kicks (1934) depicts protagonist Belacqua Shuah’s perception of the misty neon streetscape of College Green outside of Trinity College Dublin:

Bright and cheery above the strom of the Green, as though coached by the Star of Bethlehem, the Bovril sign danced and danced through its seven phases.

The TCD Miscellany made the following humorous observation in a short poem entitled Epitaph in 1951:



Here Lies one who met his fate
Just outside the College Gate;
By darkness saw he sights suburb,
With eyes aloft he left the kerb;
As from beneath the ‘bus they picked him
They murmured ‘Boveril’s latest victim’

Éamonn Mac Thomáis in his classic memoir Me jewel and darlin’ Dublin (1983) wrote that

The first illuminated sign I remember seeing in Dublin was the Bovril sign high over College Green. What a spectacle it provided as it burst into a rainbow of colours.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
O' Connell Street from Nelson's Pillar, Dublin, Irish Republic, 31 January 1959 from [http://www.flickr.com/photos/10822554@N02]'s Photostream

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/allhails/2980981659/in/photostream/]

You can see the back of the round Caltex sign on the building on the corner next to the Metropole.  This sign is NOT in our Photo.

Here is a photo from [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65176998@N00]'s photostream showing the Caltex sign at the top left.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/spudmurphy/146849427/]

I think that makes our photo Pre 31st January 1959

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content:
You might be right [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06]. There's lots of images of a smaller Caltex sign lower down the building that for a short while may have been reinstalled higher up to be eventually replaced by a bigger one?
There were still tram tracks on O Connell St.up to 1955! This picture, looking north, shows both a Jaguar Mk1 and a Fiat 600. Both cars were introduced in that year.[http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03/9046757939/sizes/o/in/photostream/] Unless the Corpo took the tracks up from South of the pillar first.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] I am with you - the 1954 is to do with the Tayto Sign, in that 1954 was the year they were formed, but I think it is unlikely that a new company regardless of how successful they were could afford one of the premier advertising spaces in the City in their first, second or third year of operation.  I would guess that we are in 1957 or 1958.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: I went searching for neon signs in action. Here's one with a range including the Bovril one that had [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] waxing so lyrical, and this one has Tayto in technicolour, 1960s and with a snazzier Aer Lingus sign beside it... P.S. I'd be happy enough, given all of the above, that 1957 or 1958 are promising dates!
